scenarioDescription:
The GJ 357 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 357 is a star with 0.34 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.34 times its radius. It is located 30.80 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 357 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 357 system


GJ 357 b

GJ 357 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory, in 2019-08, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 357 b is 1.841 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 357 b is 1.217 that of Earth. At 1.841 Earth masses, GJ 357 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 357 c

GJ 357 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory, in 2019-08, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 357 c is 3.403 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 357 c is 1.660 that of Earth. At 3.403 Earth masses, GJ 357 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 357 d

GJ 357 d was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory, in 2019-08, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.20 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 357 d is 6.102 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 357 d is 2.340 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 357 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 357, which contains 3 exoplanets and was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
name: GJ 357 - System With 3 Exolanets
